Introduction

Failure to thrive (FTT) (ie, poor weight gain, weight faltering) describes a lack of appropriate weight gain relative to a patient's age, linear growth, sex, and genetic potential.  Consensus criteria for FTT are not yet established, but proposed criteria include weight that crosses ≥2 major percentiles (eg, 25th, 10th, 5th) and is downtrending when plotted on an appropriate growth chart for gestation-corrected age and sex (

figure 1
).  FTT is typically a sign of underlying medical, nutritional, developmental, behavioral, and/or psychosocial issues that require further evaluation.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



FTT is common (affecting 5%-10% of children in resource-abundant settings) and occurs due to an imbalance between caloric intake, absorption, and expenditure, or a combination of these.  Risk factors include:



  • Inadequate caloric intake:  This is the most common cause of FTT and is often related to feeding difficulties (eg, improperly prepared formula, ineffective latch/transfer of breast milk, gastroesophageal reflux disease, pyloric stenosis, muscular dystrophy), poverty (eg, food insecurity), or abuse/neglect.
  • Malabsorption (eg, celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, chronic diarrhea, inflammatory bowel disease).
  • Increased caloric expenditure (eg, congenital heart disease, hyperthyroidism, malignancy, chronic infections [eg, HIV, tuberculosis]).

Clinical presentation



In addition to poor weight gain, patients with FTT may have muscle wasting, thin hair, dry skin, irritability, and lethargy.  In severe cases, linear growth and brain growth and development can also be affected.  In addition, secondary immunodeficiency can occur, and patients may have recurrent infections.

Diagnostic evaluation



Poor weight gain may be identified during routine examination or reported as a concern by the caregiver and requires serial weight measurements over several months.  Although no consensus criteria for diagnosis exist, the following have been proposed:



  • Weight that crosses ≥2 major percentiles (eg, 25th, 10th, 5th) and is downtrending.
  • Weight that is <2nd percentile with decreased velocity of weight gain.


Serial weight measurements must be plotted on an appropriate growth chart for gestation-corrected age and sex to meet these criteria.  If poor weight gain is present, the initial evaluation involves a thorough history and physical examination, including review of prior growth charts.  The goal is to identify contributing factors (eg, medical, nutritional, developmental/behavioral, psychosocial) for management, and additional evaluation (eg, laboratory testing, imaging) may be necessary.

History



  • Medical history:  Includes prenatal and perinatal complications (eg, prematurity, fetal growth restriction, intrauterine drug exposure), gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, vomiting, diarrhea, rumination), and chronic/recurrent infections.
  • Dietary history:  Includes frequency, volume, and type of feeds (eg, breast milk, formula, solids), as well as dietary preferences and restrictions (eg, vegetarian diet).
  • Family history:  Includes genetic disorders, as well as growth patterns of parents and siblings.
  • Developmental history:  Includes milestone achievement and social interactions.
  • Social history:  Includes family structure, caregiving skills/style, financial stability, and food security.

Physical examination



  • Growth parameters:  Include weight, length/height, head circumference, and BMI-for-age comparison.
  • Appearance:  Includes subcutaneous fat, muscle mass, skin integrity, and hair texture as indicators of nutritional status.
  • Systemic examination:  Includes cardiac murmurs (eg, congenital cardiac defects), hepatomegaly (eg, metabolic disorders, chronic infections), and neurologic abnormalities.
  • Patient-caregiver relationship:  Includes the caregiver's responsiveness to the patient's needs (eg, physical needs such as warmth and nourishment, emotional needs such as comfort and support).

Laboratory evaluation



Initial laboratory testing should be determined by history and physical examination findings and may include:



  • Complete blood count:  To evaluate for anemia (eg, folate/vitamin B12 deficiency, chronic disease) and leukocytosis (eg, chronic infection).
  • C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR):  To screen for chronic inflammation.
  • Tissue transglutaminase IgA antibody with total IgA:  To evaluate for celiac disease as a cause of malabsorption and subsequent FTT after introduction of gluten-containing foods.
  • Urinalysis:  To evaluate for urinary protein (eg, kidney disease) and glucose (eg, diabetes mellitus) loss.
  • Complete metabolic panel:  To evaluate for electrolyte derangements (eg, dehydration, metabolic disorders), as well as renal, liver, and pancreatic disease.
  • Stool studies:  To evaluate for infection (eg, ova and parasite smears, Giardia antigen, bacterial culture) and inflammatory bowel disease (eg, calprotectin, guaiac).
  • Thyroid function tests:  To evaluate for hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism.
  • Sweat chloride test:  To evaluate for cystic fibrosis.


Depending on the results of these tests, additional laboratory testing (eg, food allergy, inborn errors of metabolism [eg, serum amino acids, urine organic acids, serum carnitine profile], serologies [eg, HIV, hepatitis]) may be indicated to further evaluate for specific diagnoses on the differential.

Imaging studies



  • Chest radiograph:  To evaluate cardiac silhouette and lungs.
  • Bone age:  To assess for endocrinopathies that can affect weight gain and linear growth.
  • Abdominal ultrasonography:  To assess for structural anomalies (eg, pyloric stenosis).
  • Swallowing function study:  To evaluate swallowing mechanics.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis is broad and includes a variety of organic and nonorganic (eg, psychosocial) etiologies, as previously described.  In general, any organic disease can impair weight gain and lead to FTT.

Management



Management varies depending on the duration and severity of malnutrition and requires a multidisciplinary approach, as follows:



  • Mild malnutrition:  Managed in the outpatient setting with dietary counseling to establish a feeding plan with daily caloric intake calculated to meet the goal (ie, catch-up) weight gain.  Strategies include fortification of breast milk or formula for infants and offering of meals and snacks with calorie-dense foods (eg, butter, cheese).  Weight should be reassessed at regular intervals, and the feeding plan should be adjusted accordingly.
  • Moderate malnutrition:  Typically managed in the outpatient setting, although the goal caloric intake should be reached over 7-10 days to avoid complications associated with refeeding.
  • Severe malnutrition:  Typically managed in the inpatient setting.  Hospitalization allows for gradual refeeding to avoid gastrointestinal discomfort and electrolyte derangements as tissue mineral content changes (ie, refeeding syndrome).  Electrolyte repletion (eg, potassium, phosphate) may be necessary within 3-5 days of initiating feeds.  Caregivers should be involved in the feeding plan and demonstrate competence in administering the plan prior to discharge.


In addition to nutritional therapy, adjunctive therapies may be necessary to address underlying medical (eg, management of inflammatory bowel disease), developmental/behavioral (eg, referral to early intervention for neurodevelopmental deficits), and psychosocial issues identified by the initial diagnostic evaluation.  Child protective services should be contacted in all cases of suspected child abuse/neglect.

Prognosis



The prognosis of FTT depends on the duration and severity of malnutrition, as well as the successful management of underlying medical, developmental/behavioral, and psychosocial issues.  Although catch-up growth can be achieved with intervention, 25%-60% of patients remain small (ie, weight or length/height <20th percentile for gestation-corrected age and sex).  In addition, malnutrition is a major risk factor for neurodevelopmental impairment (eg, learning disabilities), which can impact quality of life.

Summary



Failure to thrive is a descriptive term, rather than a definitive diagnosis, that refers to a lack of appropriate weight gain (eg, weight gain that crossed downward ≥2 major percentiles) for a patient's age, length/height, sex, and genetic potential.  Management involves providing nutritional support and addressing underlying medical, nutritional, developmental/behavioral, and/or psychosocial issues.
